USOE-NAEB UTILIZATION PROJECT
FILM 4: "PROMISING PRACTICES"
I. INTRODUCTION
A. Many of the concerns which come to mind, as schools, school systems, admin¬
istrators, and teachers consider the use of television, are not insurmountable.
Principal: voices concern with scheduling problems (teacher-time,
bell periods, individual classrooms, multiple sections).
Curriculum specialist: voices concern with curriculum problems (cor¬
relating curricula of more than one school system, fitting television
lessons into prescribed courses, correlating television series with standard
texts).
Superintendent: voices concern with costs (justifying expense of tele¬
vision and finding ways to cope with expenses involved).
Special education supervisor: voices concern with using expensive mass
medium for benefit of small groups with special learning needs (justifica¬
tion and most effective ways of using).
5. Teacher: voices concern with using mass medium to develop independent
learners (uncertainties concerning efficacy with reference to individual
students and individual teachers).
B. Rim content indicated: brief glimpses of flexible and imaginative approaches
to these concerns. . . approaches which are working well in certain places
and which may offer promise for other locales.
